description: From Middle English fulsom, equivalent to ful- +‎ -some. The meaning has evolved from an original positive connotation "abundant" to a neutral "plump" to a negative "overfed". In modern usage, it can take on any of these inflections. See usage note.

The negative sense "offensive, gross; disgusting, sickening" developed secondarily after the 13th century and was influenced by Middle English foul (“foul”). In the 18th century, the word was sometimes even spelled foulsome.

entries.meaning: Offensive to good taste, tactless, overzealous, excessive.

examples: The fulsome thanks of the war-torn nation lifted our weary spirits.
Her fulsome timbre resonated throughout the hall.
